verses.text: They set out from Elim, and all the congregation of the people of Israel came to the Wilderness of Sin, which is between Elim and Sinai, on the fifteenth day of the second month after they had departed from the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: The Wilderness of Sin is a geographical location, not related to the English word 'sin.'

verses.text: And the whole congregation of the people of Israel grumbled against Moses and Aaron in the wilderness.
verses.comment: Kept 'grumbled' for consistency with commonly used modern translations.

verses.text: And the people of Israel said to them, "If only we had died by the hand of the LORD in the land of Egypt, when we sat by pots of meat and ate bread to the full, for you have brought us out into this wilderness to kill this whole assembly with hunger."
verses.comment: 'Pots of meat' retains the idiom of the original.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, "Look, I am about to rain bread from heaven for you. The people will go out and gather a day’s portion every day, so that I may test them, whether or not they will walk in my law."
verses.comment: 'Rain bread' follows the Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: On the sixth day, they are to prepare what they bring in, and it will be twice as much as they gather daily.
verses.comment: Stresses the Sabbath preparation as in the original.

verses.text: So Moses and Aaron said to all the people of Israel, "At evening you will know that it was the LORD who brought you out of the land of Egypt,
verses.comment: Kept literal phrase 'the LORD brought you out.'

verses.text: and in the morning you will see the glory of the LORD, because he has heard your grumbling against the LORD. For what are we, that you grumble against us?"
verses.comment: 'Glory of the LORD' is a common biblical phrase kept literal.

verses.text: And Moses said, "When the LORD gives you meat to eat in the evening and bread to satisfy you in the morning, because the LORD has heard your grumbling that you grumble against him—what are we? Your grumbling is not against us but against the LORD."
verses.comment: Repeated 'grumbling' for faithfulness to the Hebrew text structure.

verses.text: Then Moses said to Aaron, "Say to the entire congregation of the people of Israel, 'Come near before the LORD, for he has heard your grumbling.'"
verses.comment: ‘Come near before the LORD’ is a literal rendering.

verses.text: As Aaron spoke to the whole congregation of the people of Israel, they looked toward the wilderness, and behold, the glory of the LORD appeared in the cloud.
verses.comment: ‘Glory of the LORD appeared in the cloud’ as in original.

verses.text: And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: Kept formulaic phrase as original.

verses.text: "I have heard the grumbling of the people of Israel. Say to them, 'At twilight you will eat meat, and in the morning you will be filled with bread. Then you will know that I am the LORD your God.'"
verses.comment: 'Twilight' reflects the Hebrew 'between the evenings.'

verses.text: In the evening, quail came up and covered the camp, and in the morning there was a layer of dew around the camp.
verses.comment: ‘Quail came up and covered the camp’ kept close to Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: When the layer of dew evaporated, there on the surface of the wilderness was a fine, flaky substance, fine as frost on the ground.
verses.comment: ‘Fine as frost’ is literal from the Hebrew.

verses.text: When the people of Israel saw it, they said to one another, "What is it?" For they did not know what it was. And Moses said to them, "It is the bread that the LORD has given you to eat."
verses.comment: "What is it?" is a literal rendering of 'man hu,' the source of the term 'manna.'

verses.text: This is what the LORD has commanded: 'Gather of it, each one of you as much as he can eat. You shall take an omer per person, according to the number of your people, each one for those in his tent.'"
verses.comment: 'Omer' is a Hebrew unit, about 2.2 liters.

verses.text: And the people of Israel did so. They gathered, some more, some less.
verses.comment: Literal to the Hebrew.

verses.text: But when they measured it with an omer, whoever gathered much had nothing left over, and whoever gathered little had no lack. Each of them gathered as much as he could eat.
verses.comment: Paul quotes this verse in 2 Corinthians 8:15.

verses.text: And Moses said to them, "Let no one leave any of it over till the morning."
verses.comment: Literal prohibition preserved.

verses.text: But they did not listen to Moses. Some left part of it until the morning, and it bred worms and became foul. So Moses was angry with them.
verses.comment: ‘Became foul’ vs. ‘stank’–modern idiom used.

verses.text: Morning by morning they gathered it, each as much as he could eat. But when the sun grew hot, it melted.
verses.comment: No significant deviation.

verses.text: On the sixth day they gathered twice as much bread, two omers each. And all the leaders of the congregation came and told Moses.
verses.comment: ‘Leaders of the congregation’ is literal.

verses.text: And he said to them, "This is what the LORD has said: Tomorrow is a Sabbath of solemn rest, a holy Sabbath to the LORD. Bake what you will bake and boil what you will boil, and all that is left over set aside to be kept until the morning."
verses.comment: 'Sabbath of solemn rest' follows Hebrew 'shabbat shabbaton.'

verses.text: So they set it aside until the morning, as Moses commanded, and it did not smell bad, and there were no worms in it.
verses.comment: Literal as in previous verses.

verses.text: Moses said, "Eat it today, for today is a Sabbath to the LORD. Today you will not find it in the field.
verses.comment: Repetition for emphasis as in Hebrew.

verses.text: Six days you shall gather it, but on the seventh day, which is a Sabbath, there will be none."
verses.comment: Literal rendering.

verses.text: Yet on the seventh day some of the people went out to gather, but they found none.
verses.comment: Kept literal.

verses.text: And the LORD said to Moses, "How long will you refuse to keep my commandments and my laws?
verses.comment: "How long…" used as rhetorical rebuke, as in Hebrew.

verses.text: See, the LORD has given you the Sabbath; therefore on the sixth day he gives you bread for two days. Remain each of you in his place; let no one go out of his place on the seventh day."
verses.comment: 'Remain… in his place' kept literal. Sabbath rest emphasized.

verses.text: So the people rested on the seventh day.
verses.comment: Simple literal sentence.

verses.text: Now the house of Israel called its name manna. It was like coriander seed, white, and its taste was like wafers made with honey.
verses.comment: ‘Manna’ transliterated. Description is literal.

verses.text: And Moses said, "This is what the LORD has commanded: 'Let an omer of it be kept throughout your generations, so that they may see the bread that I fed you in the wilderness, when I brought you out of the land of Egypt.'"
verses.comment: 'Throughout your generations' is a literal Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: And Moses said to Aaron, "Take a jar and put an omer of manna in it, and place it before the LORD to be kept throughout your generations."
verses.comment: 'Jar' is a general translation of Hebrew 'tzintsenet.'

verses.text: As the LORD commanded Moses, so Aaron placed it before the Testimony to be kept.
verses.comment: 'The Testimony' refers to the tablets of the covenant.

verses.text: The people of Israel ate the manna forty years, until they came to a habitable land. They ate the manna until they came to the border of the land of Canaan.
verses.comment: 'Habitable land' (erets noshevet) is literal.

verses.text: (Now an omer is the tenth part of an ephah.)
verses.comment: Gloss included for measurement clarity, as in the Hebrew.
